text: In archaea, the S-layer serves the structural function of a cell wall.
The Gram-positive cell envelope has multiple layers of peptidoglycan, threaded by teichoic acids.
The cell wall is porous, but its network of covalent bonds generates turgor pressure that protects the cell from osmotic shock.
The S-layer of proteins is highly porous but can prevent phagocytosis and protect cells in extreme environments.
If the rod shape is curved (called a vibrio, or crescent shape), the third cytoskeletal protein, crescentin, polymerizes along the inner curve of the by a membrane-specific fluorophore.
These cytoskeletal proteins, and their variants that have evolved in other species, work together within cells to generate the shapes of bacteria.
The cell wall maintains turgor pressure.
